charts.summary: The amount of e-waste is expected to continue its rapid growth from 33.8 Metric tonnes (Mt) in 2010 to an estimated 49.8 Mt in 2018! This is an annual growth rate of approximately 5%, comprising lamps, monitors, phones, temperature exchange equipment, IT parts, tablets and so much more.

points.text: While bins for different kinds of garbage are a common sight in the U.S. and Europe, a system of separate waste collection has only recently begun to develop in Russia. Landfills, covering over 30,000 square miles in total, still represent a major environmental challenge for the country.
points.title: Paltus, Russia

points.text: China consciously worked to control the rare earth minerals market which are the key components of consumer electronic and telecommunications which dominate our daily life. However, it is here in Chhatarpur, India in the Orissa Sands Complex, where China produces approximately 25 percent of the global supply.
points.title: Chhatarpur, India

points.text: Amazon Web Services has a data center located here. China has invested heavily in "cloud cities."
points.title: Ningxia Hui, China
West Perth, Australia
points.text: The rare-earth-element (REEs) are a group of 17 metals which comprise the lanthanide series of elements: lanthanum (La), cerium (Ce), praseodymium (Pr), neodymium (Nd), promethium (Pm), samarium (Sm), europium (Eu), gadolinium (Gd), terbium (Tb), dysprosium (Dy), holmium (Ho), erbium (Er), thulium (Tm), ytterbium (Yb) and lutetium (Lu), in addition to scandium (Sc) and yttrium (Y), which show similar physical and chemical properties to the lanthanides. The REEs have unique catalytic, metallurgical, nuclear, electrical, magnetic and luminescent properties. Their strategic importance is indicated by their use in emerging and diverse technologies that are becoming increasingly more significant in today’s society.

points.title: Tamil Nadu, India
points.text: India is commissioning a plant to produce up to 5,000 tonnes of rare earths a year, a state company official told Reuters, which could help it contribute about 5 percent to the global supply of the metals used in cameras, cars, iPhones and wind turbines.

The Pasto Bueno mine in Peru has been in operation since the beginning of the century. Some 6 million tonnes of ore have been extracted, the equivalent of 42,000 tonnes of tungsten concentrate. The grade and quality of the tungsten extracted from the Pasto Bueno mine is particularly high.
points.title: Lima, Peru
Paltus, Russsia
points.text: While bins for different kinds of garbage are a common sight in the U.S. and Europe, a system of separate waste collection has only recently begun to develop in Russia. Landfills, covering over 30,000 square miles in total, still represent a major environmental challenge for the country.

Tungsten has a variety of uses, including the control of the vibration mechanism in our cell phones. Tungsten is remarkable for its robustness, especially for the fact that it has the highest melting point of all the elements. Its high density is 19.3 times that of water, comparable to that of uranium and gold, and much higher (about 1.7 times) than that of lead. Tungsten's many alloys have numerous applications, including incandescent light bulb filaments, X-ray tubes, electrodes in welding, superalloys, and radiation shielding. Tungsten's hardness and high density give it military applications in penetrating projectiles. Tungsten compounds are also often used as industrial catalysts.
points.title: Hai Phong, Vietnam

points.text: Tantalum allows Apple’s iPhone to maintain an electrical charge.
points.title: Kigali, Rwanda

points.text: Heavily armed gangs battle over gold, tin, tantalum and tungsten, also known as the "three Ts", the necessary and very rare components for our many devices.
points.title: Kinshasa, Democratic Rep. of Congo

points.text: The Basel Convention, which came into force in 1992, bans the export of hazardous waste including e-waste from developed countries to developing ones for “final disposal, recovery or recycling”.
points.title: Indonesia

points.text: Less than 2 per cent of India's total electronic waste gets recycled due to absence of proper infrastructure, legislation and framework. The country produces approximately 1.3 million metric tonnes of e-waste per annum, Assocham Secretary General D S Rawat said.
points.title: New Delhi, India

points.text: While bins for different kinds of garbage are a common sight in the U.S. and Europe, a system of separate waste collection has only recently begun to develop in Russia. Landfills, covering over 30,000 square miles in total, still represent a major environmental challenge for the country.
points.title: Paltus, Russia

points.text:
Situated about 27 km (17 miles) east of Hanoi, Dong Mai began recycling lead from used batteries in the 1970s. Tests in mid-2015 found severe lead contamination in the air, water, soil, and crops in the village, with the highest levels of more than 1,000 times the level deemed safe being found in surface water.
Lead accumulation in one’s body can cause anemia, nervous system dysfunction, weakness, hypertension, kidney problems and reproduction problems such as decreased fertility, higher risk of miscarriages, premature deliveries, and low birth weight of newborns.
points.title: Dong Mai, Vietnam

points.text: A study conducted here investigated the accumulation levels and profiles of dioxin-related compounds (DRCs) in breast milk samples from women living in two Vietnamese e-waste recycling sites (EWRSs) and estimated the intake contribution from e-waste-related exposure. The estimated intake doses for breastfed infants (1.3-33 pg/kg/d) mostly exceeded the tolerable value, especially for those living in the EWRSs.
points.title: Trang Minh, Hong Kong

points.text: Batam Island has been identified as accepting e-waste from the United States and recycling it in unsafe conditions.
points.title: Batam Island, Indonesia

points.text: A UN Environment Programme (UNEP) report estimated that 60 to 90 per cent of the world’s electronic waste is illegally dumped. Last year, nearly 42 million tonnes of e-waste were generated, and the trade in e-waste could be worth as much as US$18.8 billion a year, it says. “Many shipments of e-waste are disguised as second-hand goods,” the report says.
points.title: Accra, Ghana

points.text: If “Managed” safely by recycling, E-waste can be a secondary source of raw materials. Added benefits include generation from recovered materials, natural resource conservation and a reduction in environmental pollution.
points.title: Bangalore, India

points.text: The largest e-waste dump site in all of China. Laborers here earn under $2.00 per day extracting valuable elements from circuit boards, sometimes by burning plastic coatings around the materials or leaching off the toxic components.
points.title: Guiya, China
Bui Dau, Vietnam
points.text: Flame retardants (FRs) were released to the surrounding environment from improper recycling activities, such as manual dismantling of devices and open burning of e-wastes. Moreover, the estimated daily intakes of those FRs via soil ingestion were approximately ten times higher for children than adults.

This London data center is part of the expansion by Amazon to meet the current and future needs of users and applications that require as little latency as possible. This London location is Amazon's third in the EU, with the others being in Dublin, which opened in 2007, and Frankfurt, which opened in 2014., This location followed swiftly on the heels of the South Korea location.
points.title: London, England

points.text: Microsoft is among the three largest cloud providers in the world, with it’s Azure and Office 365 offerings placing it in the number-two spot in the market behind Amazon. Google is thought to be the third-largest in the general purpose IaaS/cloud infrastructure arena, but IBM isn’t far behind.
points.title: Manila, Philippines

points.text: Amazon Web Services has a data center located here. China has invested heavily in "cloud cities."
points.title: Ningxia Hui, China

points.text: Data center operators can implement green strategies in their existing facilities that will greatly reduce energy consumption and cooling expenditures. Boosting airflow management can reduce energy consumption by 40 percent, consolidating servers can reduce energy consumption from 10 to 40 percent and raising internal temperatures in data centers can save 60 percent on cooling costs. Innovative cooling technologies can use up to 95 percent less energy.
points.title: Osaka, Japan

points.text: Watch a guided video tour of a Google data center. From the networking room to the cooling towers outside of the facility, explore the different areas of a Google data center in this guided video tour.
points.title: Rio, Brazil

points.text: This data center enables companies in South America to run applications in the local region, cutting down on latency when applications are served to South America but processed elsewhere.
points.title: Sao Paulo, Brazil
Singapore
points.text: More new Internet users are coming online every day in Asia than anywhere else in the world. In September 2011, Google announced that they had acquired 2.45 hectares of land in Jurong West, with plans to build a data center.

points.title: Sydney, Australia
points.text: The 17 chemical elements that make up the rare earths group are, in fact, fairly commonly found, although not often in quantities that are worth extracting.
Facebook opened a data center in 2013, the first outside in high, cool latitudes reduces the cost in high, of cooling large server farms.
points.title: Lulea, Sweden

points.text: Azure is in more than 30 regions around the world, and has announced plans for 8 additional regions. Geographic expansion is a priority for Azure because it enables our customers to achieve higher performance and it support their requirements and preferences regarding data location.
points.title: Hong Kong, China

points.text: Google acquired 15 hectares of land in Changhua County, Taiwan, to build one of their first data centers in Asia. The system works by cooling water at night, when temperatures are cooler, storing the cooled water in large insulated tanks where it retains it’s temperature before being pumped throughout the facility to cool the servers during the day.
points.title: Changhua County, Taiwan

points.text: In March 2009, Google purchased the Summa Mill from Finnish paper company Stora Enso and outlined their plans to convert the 60 year old paper mill into a data center. The facility is one of the most advanced and efficient data centers in the Google fleet. The high-tech cooling system, which uses sea water from the Bay of Finland, reduces energy use and was the first of its kind anywhere in the world.
points.title: Hamina, Finland

points.text: The data center became fully operational in January 2015, and is one of the most efficient and environmentally friendly data centers in Latin America.
points.title: Quilicura, Chile

points.text: More new Internet users are coming online every day in Asia than anywhere else in the world. In September 2011, Google announced that they had acquired 2.45 hectares of land in Jurong West, with plans to build a data center.
points.title: Singapore
Singapore
points.text: More new Internet users are coming online every day in Asia than anywhere else in the world. In September 2011, Google announced that they had acquired 2.45 hectares of land in Jurong West, with plans to build a data center.

metadata.author: Addressable Media
metadata.description:
In the US, 12 million mobile phones were collected for recycling in 2011 even though 120 million were bought. Meanwhile, newer phone models are racing on to the market leaving old ones likely to end up in landfills.
Christmas will see a surge in sales and waste around the world,” says Ruediger Kuehr, Executive Secretary of StEP. “The explosion is happening because there’s so much technical innovation. TVs, mobile phones and computers are all being replaced more and more quickly. The lifetime of products is also shortening.
E-waste — which extends from old fridges to toys and even motorized toothbrushes — is now the world’s fastest growing waste stream. China generated 11.1 million tonnes last year, followed by the US with 10 million tonnes…By 2017, Kuehr expects the volume of end-of-life TVs, phones, computers, monitors, e-toys and other products to be enough to fill a 15,000-mile line of 40-tonne lorries.
Although it is legal to export discarded goods to poor countries if they can be reused or refurbished, much is being sent to Africa or Asia under false pretences, says Interpol. Treatment in these countries usually occurs in the informal sector, causing significant environmental pollution and health risks for local populations,” he said.
John Vidal, The Guardian
metadata.name: Global E-Waste
metadata.summary: Electronics have forever enhanced our lives. However, the byproducts of these life changing wonders has created the fastest growing stream of hazardous materials, “E-waste.” Highly toxic components must be disposed of properly.
